newsitem.title: MEXICO: MEXICO CETES RATE EASES DOWN ON U.S. LONG BOND.
newsitem.headline: MEXICO CETES RATE EASES DOWN ON U.S. LONG BOND.

text.p: Mexican overnight Cetes rates were down five basis points to 18.75 percent in early trade on Monday.
Dealers said rates had zigzagged on fluctuating U.S. long bond yields and pressures from big players with hefty liquidity positions to obtain higher returns.

"The long bond is going up and down. Mild U.S. inflation data have had a positive impact on our market via U.S. markets, but the sharp changes will make dealers cautious," a fixed-income analyst said.
The U.S. 30-year Treasury bond was up 10/32 to yield 6.65 percent in early trade.
The analyst added that gains in domestic rates at Tuesday night's auction had cushioned falls in secondary market rates.
Banco de Mixico placed bellwether 28-day Cetes at 18.36 percent, a gain of 36 basis points since last week's auction.
Overnight rates on bank paper paralleled government rates, and fell five basis points to 18.95 percent.
Liquidity of 954 million pesos was due to return to the system from prior central bank operations. Dealers said an estimated 200 million pesos in cash was also expected to flow into the market.
